posts.cooked: Would it be possible to add an option to have ones own number excluded from the server’s response? In practice this would probably mean that the server would need to store the user’s preference and check it before sending the contact discovery results to the client.

link_counts.title: How to join and block at once?
I don't want contact sync on Android & Dektop. How to do?
Why are users (who have my phone number in their contacts) notified that I've joined Signal?
Is there confusion of "usernames" vs. "phone number privacy" and if so, how can it be avoided?

posts.name: Fer K.
posts.cooked:
Personally, I think there should be an option to prevent the server from advertising to other people that I use signal.

I actually wouldn’t mind if it worked the other way around (me advertising to people in my contacts that I have signal), but I do not like the fact that I do not have control over who is receiving information about my phone number being an active signal user.

This can be misused by spammers, like it was shown in: Spam/Scam on Signal

link_counts.title: Spam/Scam on Signal
Why are users (who have my phone number in their contacts) notified that I've joined Signal?

posts.cooked:
Ferkv:

This can be misused by spammers, like it was shown in: Spam/Scam on Signal

Note that spammers don’t need discoverability to spam – they can just attempt to send messages anyway.

There’s work in progress for it on the Android side.

signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/58c4582f15ad01e1de33fb8857d131d51df514e9/app/src/main/java/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/keyvalue/PhoneNumberPrivacyValues.java#L82-L93

    2. 
          
  2.   LISTED,
    3.

    4. 
          
  4.

    6.

    7.

link_counts.title: Signal-Android/PhoneNumberPrivacyValues.java at 58c4582f15ad01e1de33fb8857d131d51df514e9 · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub

posts.cooked: So let me get this straight… They can do it so why should we make it harder for them?
It doesn’t make it any harder. They just send messages to a list of numbers regardless.

I’m saying it’s not sufficient; lists of phone numbers can be obtained in other ways. They also don’t need to know whether they are valid Signal accounts in order to send spam to them. You would need something that prevented non-contacts from messaging you at all (eg, whitelisting), but in that case, non-discoverability is not necessary to prevent spam.

posts.name: EC
posts.cooked:
The most valid use case I have in mind for this would be for a survivor of abuse who NEEDS services like this to communicate with the world outside of the limits of control.

When Signal broadcasts this information, their (increasingly tech-aware) abuser is automatically made aware that they’re creating alternate means of contact to sidestep controls and the service is dangerous for their safety.

To Signal devs, please prioritize this work that’s already in the codebase, please don’t treat these scenarios as externalities. Not every aspect of social media needs emulating ;)

Thanks!

I don’t know whether discoverability is limited to the CDS stuff. This would be the soft version. The hard version would mean that people can’t send messages to you without some additional knowledge. This can be useful for those who publish identifiers too.

Why are users (who have my phone number in their contacts) notified that I've joined Signal?

Someone could try to initiate a chat with me by pressing the pencil button, entering name or number, and so on. Since my number is privately registered anyone who does the above should get the “unsecured sms or enable signal for sms” option.

Why are users (who have my phone number in their contacts) notified that I've joined Signal?

The natural question is how do two privately registered users start talking on Signal. This is the only part which requires some implementation work. Maybe one user sets a temporary 6 digit number. The other user enters the phone number followed by say two ## followed by the 6 digit number. Signal checks that the 6 digit numbers match and starts Signal conversation. If time has elapsed or numbers don’t match fall back to sms.

link_counts.title: What hurts you more, people who only have WhatsApp or people who start using Telegram instead of Signal?

posts.cooked:
Is it enough to set this boolean and trigger the update by toggling the “allow from anyone” setting?

~~Signal-Android/RefreshAttributesJob.java at main · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub
EDIT: I guess just turning on the feature flag is enough?

There are lots of questions on how they’ve implemented discoverability. Is it just the SGX enclave which is leaving out these phone numbers or is the entire server pretending these numbers don’t exist? What do people you’ve chatted with see? Can they continue sending messages? What about people to whom you send a first message? What about groups which have people you’ve not chatted with? How can two nondiscoverable phone# start a chat?

link_counts.title: Signal-Android/RefreshAttributesJob.java at main · signalapp/Signal-Android · GitHub

posts.cooked:
My comments are based on the current iteration of code and I am not an employee of signal foundation. The code is subject to change and parts are not ready so I do not recommend using this yet. (f.e. the signal-desktop client will use sender certificate with UUID and e164 instead of the UUID-only certificate, so it will reveal your phone number if you use the desktop client right now).

Please don’t distribute forks that turn this on, because signal does not especially like you to use forks and all of these is not stable yet as I have explained. It can be dangerous for people that need it.

newuser:

Is it just the SGX enclave which is leaving out these phone numbers or is the entire server pretending these numbers don’t exist?

CDS repo on github has not been updated since 2019, so we can only speculate. But my guess is that CDS does not return any phone numbers to the UUID mapping which for clients they interpret as unregistered. So you can’t send a message to a user that is undiscoverable, at least using the unmodified apps.

The following comment provides us some more.

github.com

signalapp/Signal-iOS/blob/main/SignalServiceKit/src/Contacts/Discovery/ContactDiscoveryTask.swift#L110-L121


      
    
          
  1. // by CDS lookups.
    2. 
          
  2. //
    3. 
          
  3. // When any of these scenarios occur, we cannot know with certainty if the
    4. 
          
  4. // user is unregistered or has only turned off discoverability, so we
    5. 
          
  5. // *only* mark the addresses without any UUIDs as unregistered. Everything
    6. 
          
  6. // else we ignore; we will identify their current registration status
    7. 
          
  7. // either when attempting to send a message or when fetching their profile.
    8. 
          
  8. let recipient = recipientDatabaseTable.fetchRecipient(phoneNumber: phoneNumber.stringValue, transaction: tx)
    9. 
          
  9. guard let recipient, recipient.aci == nil, recipient.pni == nil else {
    10. 
          
  10.     return
    11. 
          
  11. }
    12. 
          
  12. recipientManager.markAsUnregisteredAndSave(recipient, unregisteredAt: .now, shouldUpdateStorageService: true, tx: tx)
    13.

This is the log when I type in my own number into search and press “New message to…”

ContactsDatabase: Adding number: +**********xx
DirectoryHelper: [single] e164-network: 5010  e164-disk: 266  total: 5276
PassphraseRequiredActivity: routeApplicationState(), state: 0
BaseActivity: [ConversationActivity] onCreate()
ConversationActivity: Setting wallpaper.
ConversationActivity: handleSecurityChange(false, true)
ConversationActivity: Resolving registered state...
ConversationActivity: Checking through resolved recipient
ConversationActivity: Resolved registered state: NOT_REGISTERED
ConversationActivity: Returning registered state...

It is calling the function ContactDiscoveryV2.getDirectoryResult and result.getRegisteredNumbers().size() is 0 so the app never knows the e164-UUID mapping.

https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android/blob/master/app/src/main/java/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/contacts/sync/DirectoryHelper.java#L158

newuser:

What do people you’ve chatted with see? Can they continue sending messages? What about people to whom you send a first message?

When you chat with someone, they will know your UUID because it is included in your sender certificate. Of course sending a message also shares your profile so they will see the profile information. The app will use your UUID to check your registration status and so the app will let them send messages. If you have set “See my phone number” to “Nobody” they will not be able to see your phone number.

newuser:

What about groups which have people you’ve not chatted with?

They will see the profile information and they will be able to start a chat with you. If you have set “See my phone number” to “Nobody” they will not be able to see your phone number.

newuser:

How can two nondiscoverable phone# start a chat?

The future is the username system. But one way is to be in mutual group. To this end, send a group link that requires invitation, then when people send an invite, you can start a chat with them, without accepting their invite.

Here is a group link to prove this works with the current system. If you talk to me, be aware that you will share your number: I will likely just send memes. Signal Group

posts.name: Fer K.
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

Note that spammers don’t need discoverability to spam – they can just attempt to send messages anyway.

The issue is that spammers can use signal to collect lists of phone numbers that are active phone accounts they can use for spamming in other services that use phone numbers, even outside of signal. I don’t feel comfortable knowing that anyone can start asking the signal servers with random phones and build up a list of targets in which I might be in.

It’d be better if they send the message and get no feedback so they can’t know whether I received it or not, whether I’m a signal user or not, or whether the phone was valid or not. When I know the person, I’ll answer, but if I don’t know the person it should be possible to keep private the fact that my phone number has a signal account.

It would also be more discouraging for the spammer, since they would not be able to get any information unless the user actually replies (and in that case it would be the user’s fault, not signal’s).

Imho, even the display picture should be kept private until I decide to answer back or add them to my contact list.

posts.name: EC
posts.cooked:
Technically possible but with economics of scamming it’s far easier for spammers to send out messages to any possible generated number within a block than it is to give a fig about validity of “active” number. It’s much cheaper time and moneywise to send out broad blasts than develop a curated list, and the spammer is ultimately selling that limited spam service, not the product. It’s not in their monetary interest to bother curating such lists.

I still want the option to not be involved with the “network effect” of Signal but anyone scraping details and mapping numbers to Signal accounts will be using it for different undesirable purposes than spam IMO.

posts.name: EC
posts.cooked:
I appreciate that this is stable and possible already in code, though the clients I’d be representing are not generally experienced in running a build environment and custom binaries are not really a useful part of their safety plan.

It is good to know that it would only require minor UI modifications to go live, I’m sure there are many many stories getting in the way but hopefully the Signal team can pull it up as tech debt at some point. And currently, getting by on advising persons of this potential externality in their safety plan so it can be balanced with the need for separate and secure communication.

Ferkv:

The issue is that spammers can use signal to collect lists of phone numbers that are active phone accounts they can use for spamming in other services that use phone numbers, even outside of signal.

The spammers don’t care, and even if they did, they could already get lists much more easily from any number of other services or methods. They don’t need to set up something to find “active” numbers via Signal’s contact discovery.

Ferkv:

even the display picture should be kept private until I decide to answer back or add them to my contact list.

That’s how it is now; your profile is not shared unless you accept the message request.

posts.name: Malstroem Phi
posts.cooked:
Signal is very big on privacy, yet it does not allow me to decide whether or not someone with my number should be aware I use signal and that I’m still alive for that matter. This is to me a big breach in privacy: me using signal, or me using my phone are two informations I want to have control over. I should be able to specify exactly who should know.

I think Signal needs an option to disable contact discovery. One should be able to choose if he wants everybody to easily see him on Signal or just allow a few contacts to know about me using signal. This would be an option that Signal would actively ask you at install or on the first opening.

Here is the story: I asked my father to install Signal, like many of us, his phone number was leaked and distributed to many people. He is also quite famous in his field and often solicited by job seekers in social media etc. So he is very sensitive to privacy, spam and other social solicitation. Once he installed the app he instantly received many messages like “long time no see, how are you doing?” from people he never heard of (or don’t remember, he told me they are not in his address book), he un-installed the app straight away. That’s a shame because I love the app otherwise.

In Signal’s doc they argue they want to let people know that they can contact you through Signal instead of insecure text. That’s kind of a weak argument in my opinion as it should be the user responsibility to make that call. I see it rather as a marketing attempt to encourage as many people as possible to use the app over privacy concerns. I understand the dilemma but users should be made aware of that and asked for consent like you would do for any other information.

Sorry if sounds like a rant, I really love the app and I’m sadden this is preventing me to use with people that don’t like contact discovery.

Malstroem_Phi:

This is to me a big breach in privacy: me using signal, or me using my phone are two informations I want to have control over. I should be able to specify exactly who should know.

You don’t use WhatsApp, then?

Malstroem_Phi:

Once he installed the app he instantly received many messages like “long time no see, how are you doing?” from people he never heard of (or don’t remember, he told me they are not in his address book), he un-installed the app straight away.

He would have to accept the “many messages” , or there is an option to block the sender. Perhaps it’s the cynic in me, but can you clarify what you mean by “many messages”? They don’t need to be in your father’s address book, but he can be in theirs.

Malstroem_Phi:

this is preventing me to use with people that don’t like contact discovery.

If it’s really an issue and they’re only used to plain SMS, as they can’t be using WhatsApp following what you have written, then perhaps it’s not the app for them? As an avid user yourself, you can point them in the direction of the ‘Block’ button. It takes around half a second each time. This could be frustrating, but it’s highly unlikely there would be a huge amount of people messaging to warrant it being more than a nuisance?

As you can see from a few posts above yours, the support for optional discoverability is there but it looks like it got de-prioritized and full support was postponed.

As a workaround, you could sign up with any number where you can receive the verification code via sms/call. Landlines, VoIP, etc.

anon94207282:

This could be frustrating, but it’s highly unlikely there would be a huge amount of people messaging to warrant it being more than a nuisance?

I don’t know what they were using before. Even WA doesn’t create notifications which can trigger these sort of unwanted conversations. Looks like this creates enough bad impressions/privacy issues that it has been decided to make it optional.

newuser:

Even WA doesn’t create notifications which can trigger these sort of unwanted conversations. Looks like this creates enough bad impressions/privacy issues

Indeed it doesn’t, but WhatsApp does allow people the following:

  1. That you have / had a WhatsApp ‘account’, irrespective of whether you have them in your phone book (same as Signal)
  2. To contact you as they see fit (same as Signal)
  3. See whether or not you’re ‘Online’. This is my biggest issue - irrespective of your Status being allowed to ‘Contacts Only’ or ‘Just Me’, the Online/Offline is viewable by all

Hence my reply to the post, in their opening statement, which said:

Malstroem_Phi:

yet it does not allow me to decide whether or not someone with my number should be aware I use signal and that I’m still alive for that matter.

So, I see your point RE ‘Trigger’ is a good one. The fact remains, should someone scan their Signal address book and see me in their contacts, they can contact me. Same as they could on WhatsApp. If that happened, the function is there to block them and that solves the issue.

That’s why I cannot see the “big breach in privacy” just because someone knows you have downloaded an app. I also have the following apps, if of interest to anyone in the slightest: Game Center, NordVPN, ProtonMail, Waze, Audible, Nationwide (banking), Apple Store, Trading212, eToro, the weather … and so on …
If that is of interest to anyone, I mean great. Whatever floats your boat.
The biggest breach in privacy would be for an application to default advertising when I am Online/Offline and, worst of all, making it mandatory.

newuser:

As a workaround, you could sign up with any number where you can receive the verification code via sms/call. Landlines, VoIP, etc.

This is a good alternative. Although I’ve often wondered how one is going to contact others on the Signal platform? Surely, heaven forbid, the person signing up to an alternative number wouldn’t upload a copy of their existing contacts to the new ‘account’ and use contact discovery. That’s a “big preach in privacy”, apparently.
